moves.3. d4: NxPe5 is surprisingly popular for white, but the outcomes appear generally bleak for black.
moves.3... exd4 4. Nxd4 a6 5. Qg4 d6 6. Ne6: Black can attack with Qe7.  White could respond with Bc4, but this isn't enough--black parries with Pb5 and white retreats to Bb3...  I guess that works out well for white.
moves.6... Bxe6: Or black can simply trade bishop for knight.
moves.7. Qxe6+ Qe7 8. Qc4 b5 9. Qb4 c6: Black might have preferred not to move that pawn, but the knight there instead.  This would develop a better piece, and release the rook while pushing the white queen.
moves.10. Nc3 g6 11. g3 Bh6 12. f4 f5 13. Be2: Black leaves Pd6 to the white's rook wolf.
moves.16. f5: This pawn sacrifice seems ill advised.  Oh, never mind--BxBh6.  Black might trade bishops instead, and net a free pawn.
moves.16... Bxc1 17. Raxc1 Rd8 18. Qb3+ Kg7 19: Black should be aware of the threat of Rg8#.  Nf6 no longer defends g8.  Black is advised to play Qe6, or perhaps even better--Pd5.
